DOC.brief_summary: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is used in premature infants to maintain lungs open and facilitate gas exchange. When ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch is present, areas of the lung that are open for gas exchange do not match up with the areas of the lung that are receiving blood for gas exchange. This study measure the responsiveness of V/Q mismatch to changes in the amount (or level) of CPAP.
DOC.brief_title: Impact of CPAP Level on V/Q Mismatch in Premature Infants
DOC.criteria: 1. Born at 2835 weeks gestational age (GA) by best obstetric estimate, determined by the clinical obstetric team during antepartum admission. 2. Chronologic age of 24 hours to 28 days, measured from time and date of birth. 3. On continuous CPAP support between 48 cm H2O for greater than 24 hours, as document on the bedside infant flow sheet. 4. Supplemental oxygen requirement, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) 0.25 for at least 2 consecutive hours, as documented on the bedside infant flow sheet. 1. Congenital anomalies, as determined by the clinical supervising physician. 2. Current or prior air leak syndrome, as determined by the clinical supervising physician.
